channel.title: Comments on: Tire Fitment: Stretch or No Stretch?

item.title: By: Tracy High
item.dc:creator: Tracy High
item.description:
In reply to <a href="https://grandmighty.github.io/grandmighty/2011/02/tire-fitment-stretch-or-no-stretch/#comment-78867">tikz</a>.
I have a 07 civic with 16x7 wheels and i want a slight stretch or i want my tires to look meaty not sure what size to get, my stock tires are 205/55r16
item.content:encoded:
In reply to tikz.

I have a 07 civic with 16×7 wheels and i want a slight stretch or i want my tires to look meaty not sure what size to get, my stock tires are 205/55r16

item.title: By: Dave
item.dc:creator: Dave
item.description:
In terms of performance, the rim width should be equal to the TREAD width for optimum tire performance. As far as technical correctness, any tire will have a rim width range that is acceptable and part of the spec. You should be able to find it on a tire's manufacturer's site, or a place like tire rack.
As far as the examples show, A is my limit for bulge. B and C are perfect. D is my limit and likely has the rim as wide as the SECTION width, there. and E, F and G look stupid. Something like negative A or beyond would also look stupid.
Seriously, if you can't get by on D, you need to widebody/flare it some more or just deal with the skinnier wheels and tires. Same goes for A, if you want a wider tire after A, you need to get wider wheels. Otherwise, you're just screwing yourself and looking ignorant at the same time.
item.content:encoded:
In terms of performance, the rim width should be equal to the TREAD width for optimum tire performance. As far as technical correctness, any tire will have a rim width range that is acceptable and part of the spec. You should be able to find it on a tire’s manufacturer’s site, or a place like tire rack.

As far as the examples show, A is my limit for bulge. B and C are perfect. D is my limit and likely has the rim as wide as the SECTION width, there. and E, F and G look stupid. Something like negative A or beyond would also look stupid.

Seriously, if you can’t get by on D, you need to widebody/flare it some more or just deal with the skinnier wheels and tires. Same goes for A, if you want a wider tire after A, you need to get wider wheels. Otherwise, you’re just screwing yourself and looking ignorant at the same time.

item.title: By: Eric
item.dc:creator: Eric
item.description: ^ well put. It really does depend on the car and use... but for most cases D is win
item.content:encoded: ^ well put. It really does depend on the car and use… but for most cases D is win

item.title: By: Kevin
item.dc:creator: Kevin
item.description:
I personally love the "slight stretch" look.. my e30 has about the same stretch as D, and its the perfect look to me. G is just ridiculous, and even F is too much unless u have the right car.. E is the most stretch i like.
mostly, my tire fitment preference greatly depends on the car, some cars need meaty, some need stretch.. there is no "universal" fitment.
item.content:encoded:
I personally love the “slight stretch” look.. my e30 has about the same stretch as D, and its the perfect look to me. G is just ridiculous, and even F is too much unless u have the right car.. E is the most stretch i like.

mostly, my tire fitment preference greatly depends on the car, some cars need meaty, some need stretch.. there is no “universal” fitment.

item.title: By: Eric
item.dc:creator: Eric
item.description: werd. slightly stretching a tire will also add the benefit of increased sidewall stiffness as well, without sacrificing a considerable amount of contact patch.
item.content:encoded: werd. slightly stretching a tire will also add the benefit of increased sidewall stiffness as well, without sacrificing a considerable amount of contact patch.
